Symptoms: Sudden fever, stiff neck, severe headache, nausea, vomiting, confusion, sensitivity to light, seizures
Note: Symptoms can vary between bacterial (more severe) and viral meningitis.

Symptoms: Skin lesions, numbness, muscle weakness, thickened nerves, ulcers on the soles of the feet
Note: Leprosy primarily affects the skin, nerves, and mucous membranes.

Symptoms: Muscle stiffness, jaw cramping (lockjaw), trouble swallowing, seizures, fever, sweating, high blood pressure, rapid heart rate
Note: Tetanus is caused by a bacterial toxin and is preventable through vaccination.

Symptoms: Fever, chills, headache, back pain, muscle aches, fatigue, jaundice, bleeding, organ failure in severe cases
Note: Yellow fever is a mosquito-borne viral disease.

Symptoms: High fever, weakness, stomach pain, headache, loss of appetite, constipation or diarrhea, rash
Note: Caused by Salmonella typhi, often spread through contaminated food or water.

Symptoms: Fever, headache, excess salivation, muscle spasms, paralysis, confusion, hydrophobia (fear of water)
Note: Rabies is almost always fatal once symptoms appear.

Symptoms: Diarrhea, gas, greasy stools, stomach cramps, nausea, dehydration, fatigue
Note: Caused by the parasite Giardia lamblia, often from contaminated water.

Symptoms: Diarrhea, bloating, gas, fatigue, weight loss, anemia, skin rash (dermatitis herpetiformis)
Note: Triggered by gluten consumption in genetically predisposed individuals.

Symptoms: Red, scaly skin patches, itching, burning, dry and cracked skin, thickened nails, joint pain (psoriatic arthritis)
Note: An autoimmune condition with no cure, but symptoms can be managed.

Symptoms: Fatigue, weakness, pale skin, shortness of breath, dizziness, cold hands and feet, chest pain
Note: Can result from iron deficiency, vitamin B12 deficiency, or chronic disease.

Symptoms: Painful urination, pus-like discharge, swollen testicles, increased vaginal discharge, pelvic pain
Note: A sexually transmitted infection caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

Symptoms: Painless sores, skin rashes, mucous membrane lesions, fever, swollen lymph nodes, neurological symptoms in late stages
Note: Progresses in stages if untreated; can cause severe complications.

Symptoms: Fever, sore throat, headache, vomiting, stiffness in neck and back, paralysis in severe cases
Note: Polio is now rare due to widespread vaccination.

Symptoms: Fever, muscle aches, dizziness, gastrointestinal issues, coughing, shortness of breath
Note: Caused by exposure to rodent droppings or urine.

Symptoms: Thin, grayish-white vaginal discharge with a fishy odor, burning during urination, itching
Note: Caused by an imbalance of vaginal bacteria.

Symptoms: Flu-like symptoms, swollen lymph nodes, muscle aches, eye issues (blurred vision), confusion in severe cases
Note: Caused by the parasite Toxoplasma gondii, often from undercooked meat or cat feces.

Symptoms: Cough, shortness of breath, high fever, muscle aches, headaches, gastrointestinal symptoms
Note: Caused by Legionella bacteria, often from contaminated water systems.

Symptoms: Red rash, sore throat, high fever, "strawberry" tongue, flushed face, skin peeling
Note: Caused by group A Streptococcus bacteria.

Symptoms: Excessive bleeding, easy bruising, joint pain and swelling, prolonged bleeding after injury or surgery
Note: A genetic disorder affecting blood clotting.

Symptoms: Sudden fever, chills, headache, weakness, swollen lymph nodes (bubonic plague), chest pain (pneumonic plague)
Note: Rare but serious; transmitted by fleas or respiratory droplets.

Symptoms: Eye pain, blurred vision, headache, halos around lights, nausea, vision loss in severe cases
Note: Often asymptomatic in early stages; regular eye exams are crucial.

Symptoms: Abdominal pain, cramping, bloating, gas, diarrhea, constipation, or both
Note: A functional gastrointestinal disorder with no known cure.

Symptoms: Salty-tasting skin, persistent cough, lung infections, wheezing, poor growth, digestive issues
Note: A genetic disorder affecting the lungs and digestive system.

Symptoms: Rectal bleeding, itching, discomfort, swelling around the anus, pain during bowel movements
Note: Often caused by straining during bowel movements or pregnancy.

Symptoms: Upper abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, fever, rapid pulse, back pain, tenderness in the abdomen
Note: Can be acute or chronic; often linked to gallstones or alcohol use.

Symptoms: Sudden, severe joint pain (often in the big toe), swelling, redness, warmth, stiffness
Note: Caused by uric acid crystal buildup in joints.

Symptoms: Pelvic pain, painful periods, pain during intercourse, infertility, fatigue, digestive issues
Note: A condition where tissue similar to the uterine lining grows outside the uterus.

Symptoms: Intense headache, nausea, vomiting, sensitivity to light and sound, visual disturbances (aura)
Note: Often triggered by stress, hormonal changes, or certain foods.

Symptoms: Burning sensation during urination, frequent urge to urinate, cloudy or strong-smelling urine, pelvic pain
Note: More common in women; can affect the bladder (cystitis) or kidneys (pyelonephritis).

Symptoms: Fatigue, sore throat, fever, swollen lymph nodes, headache, skin rash, soft and swollen spleen
Note: Caused by the Epstein-Barr virus (EBV).

Symptoms: Diarrhea, vomiting, abdominal cramps, fever, dehydration, headache
Note: Often caused by viruses (e.g., norovirus) or bacteria.

Symptoms: Muscle weakness, twitching, slurred speech, difficulty swallowing, breathing problems
Note: A progressive neurodegenerative disease.

Symptoms: Frequent heartburn, difficulty swallowing, chest pain, regurgitation, chronic cough
Note: A complication of chronic acid reflux.

Symptoms: Chest pain or discomfort, shortness of breath, nausea, cold sweats, fatigue, lightheadedness
Note: Symptoms can differ in women (e.g., jaw pain, fatigue).

Symptoms: High fever, joint pain, headache, muscle pain, rash, joint swelling
Note: A mosquito-borne viral disease.

Symptoms: Sore throat, difficulty swallowing, red and swollen tonsils, white or yellow coating, fever, bad breath
Note: Can be caused by viruses or bacteria (e.g., strep throat).

Symptoms: Severe coughing fits, whooping sound when inhaling, vomiting after coughing, exhaustion
Note: Preventable through vaccination.

Symptoms: Ear pain, trouble hearing, fluid drainage, fever, irritability in children
Note: Common in children; often follows a cold.

Symptoms: Sudden pain in the lower right abdomen, nausea, vomiting, fever, loss of appetite, constipation or diarrhea
Note: Requires immediate medical attention to prevent rupture.

Symptoms: Rapid breathing, confusion, fever, rapid heart rate, low blood pressure, chills, extreme discomfort
Note: A life-threatening response to infection.

Symptoms: Fever, chills, cough, sore throat, runny or stuffy nose, muscle or body aches, headaches, fatigue
Note: Caused by influenza viruses; seasonal vaccines are available for prevention.

Symptoms: Fever, dry cough, fatigue, loss of taste or smell, shortness of breath, sore throat, headache, muscle pain
Note: Caused by the SARS-CoV-2 virus; vaccination and booster doses are recommended for prevention.

Symptoms: High fever, chills, sweating, headache, nausea, vomiting, muscle pain, fatigue
Note: Caused by Plasmodium parasites transmitted through mosquito bites; common in tropical regions.

Symptoms: Persistent cough (sometimes with blood), chest pain, weight loss, fever, night sweats, fatigue
Note: Caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis; treatable with antibiotics but drug-resistant strains exist.

Symptoms: Increased thirst, frequent urination, extreme hunger, unexplained weight loss, fatigue, blurred vision, slow-healing sores
Note: Type 1 is an autoimmune condition; Type 2 is often linked to lifestyle factors. Requires lifelong management.

Symptoms: Often asymptomatic, but severe cases may include headaches, dizziness, blurred vision, chest pain, or shortness of breath
Note: A major risk factor for heart disease and stroke; managed with lifestyle changes and medication.

Symptoms: Shortness of breath, wheezing, chest tightness, coughing (especially at night or early morning)
Note: A chronic inflammatory condition of the airways; triggers include allergens, exercise, and stress.

Symptoms: High fever, severe headache, pain behind the eyes, joint and muscle pain, rash, mild bleeding (e.g., nose or gums)
Note: A mosquito-borne viral disease; severe cases can lead to dengue hemorrhagic fever.

Symptoms: Fatigue, fever, abdominal pain, dark urine, joint pain, jaundice (yellowing of skin and eyes)
Note: Caused by the hepatitis B virus (HBV); preventable with vaccination.

Symptoms: Cough (with phlegm), fever, chills, difficulty breathing, chest pain, fatigue, confusion (in older adults)
Note: Can be caused by bacteria, viruses, or fungi; vaccines are available for some types.

Symptoms: Memory loss, confusion, difficulty with language, disorientation, mood swings, behavioral changes
Note: A progressive neurodegenerative disease; no cure, but treatments can slow progression.

Symptoms: Fever, chills, rash, night sweats, muscle aches, sore throat, fatigue, swollen lymph nodes, weight loss
Note: Caused by the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV); antiretroviral therapy (ART) can manage the condition.

Symptoms: Severe diarrhea, vomiting, dehydration, muscle cramps, rapid heart rate, low blood pressure
Note: Caused by Vibrio cholerae; spread through contaminated water; preventable with proper sanitation.

Symptoms: Fever, severe headache, muscle pain, weakness, diarrhea, vomiting, abdominal pain, unexplained bleeding
Note: A severe, often fatal disease caused by the Ebola virus; outbreaks occur primarily in Africa.

Symptoms: Bullseye-shaped rash, fever, chills, headache, fatigue, muscle and joint aches, swollen lymph nodes
Note: Caused by Borrelia burgdorferi bacteria transmitted through tick bites.

Symptoms: Tremors, stiffness, slow movement, impaired balance, speech changes, writing changes
Note: A progressive nervous system disorder; treatment focuses on symptom management.

Symptoms: Sudden numbness or weakness (especially on one side of the body), confusion, trouble speaking, vision problems, dizziness, severe headache
Note: A medical emergency caused by interrupted blood flow to the brain; time is critical for treatment.

Symptoms: Unexplained weight loss, fatigue, persistent pain, skin changes, unusual bleeding, lumps or swelling, changes in bowel or bladder habits
Note: Early detection improves outcomes; treatment varies by type and stage.

Symptoms: Joint pain, swelling, stiffness (especially in the morning), fatigue, fever, loss of appetite
Note: An autoimmune disorder; treatment includes medications and lifestyle changes.

Symptoms: Mild fever, rash, joint pain, conjunctivitis (red eyes), muscle pain, headache
Note: A mosquito-borne virus; can cause birth defects if contracted during pregnancy.

Symptoms: High fever, cough, runny nose, red eyes, rash (starts on the face and spreads), small white spots inside the mouth
Note: Highly contagious; preventable with the MMR vaccine.

Symptoms: Itchy rash, fever, headache, fatigue, loss of appetite
Note: Caused by the varicella-zoster virus; preventable with vaccination.

Symptoms: Shortness of breath, chronic cough, wheezing, chest tightness, frequent respiratory infections
Note: Often caused by smoking; includes chronic bronchitis and emphysema.

Symptoms: Hallucinations, delusions, disorganized thinking, lack of motivation, social withdrawal, impaired cognitive function
Note: A chronic mental health disorder; treatment includes antipsychotic medications and therapy.

Symptoms: Numbness or weakness in limbs, vision problems, fatigue, dizziness, electric-shock sensations with neck movements
Note: An autoimmune disease affecting the central nervous system; no cure, but treatments can slow progression.

Symptoms: Fatigue, joint pain, rash (butterfly-shaped on the face), fever, hair loss, sensitivity to sunlight
Note: An autoimmune disease; symptoms vary widely and can affect multiple organs.

Symptoms: Often asymptomatic until a fracture occurs; may include back pain, loss of height, stooped posture
Note: A condition of weakened bones; prevention includes calcium, vitamin D, and weight-bearing exercise.

Symptoms: Fatigue, weight gain, cold intolerance, dry skin, hair loss, constipation, depression
Note: Caused by an underactive thyroid gland; treated with synthetic thyroid hormone.

Symptoms: Weight loss, rapid heartbeat, sweating, nervousness, irritability, tremors, heat intolerance
Note: Caused by an overactive thyroid gland; treatment includes medications, radioactive iodine, or surgery.

Symptoms: Bullseye-shaped rash, fever, chills, headache, fatigue, muscle and joint aches, swollen lymph nodes
Note: Caused by Borrelia burgdorferi bacteria transmitted through tick bites.
